prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Probing the dust emission and submm excess in Band 7 in NGC 7793
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to map the dust continuum emission and the CO(3-2) line emission with ALMA in Band 7 in an extranuclear region of NGC7793. We aim to characterise the location of the submm emission that appears in excess compared to Herschel predictions by comparing it with other tracers of the interstellar medium. A 2" resolution will allow us to spatially relate the regions where the cold dust dominates with the PAH carriers or with the molecular gas reservoirs at the same resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to observe the dust continuum and the CO(3-2) line at 345 GHz in band 7 in NGC7793. We choose an angular resolution of 2” in order to match the resolution of the Spitzer/8μm maps (1.9” resolution). This will allow to spatially compare the distribution of the cold dust distribution with respect to the PAH carriers as well as the molecular gas reservoirs.
For the correlator setup, we select the single continuum spectral type, with dual polarisation and 4 spectral windows. The setups for band 7 will also allow us to obtain a CO(3-2) line measurement at the same angular resolution. This will be the first resolved mapping of the molecular gas reservoir in this object. We choose a sky frequency of 344.0 GHz to include the CO(3-2) line in Baseband-2. We choose a bandwidth of 2000 MHz (large velocity range for continuum measurements), with an element resolution of 31.250 MHz, resulting in a velocity resolution of 27.9 km/s.
We are requesting an extranuclear mosaic of 50” by 22”, with an position angle of 172 ̊. This mosaic will require 17 pointings (using the default Nyquist sampling) of the 12m array. The sensitivity required is estimated in order to allow the detection of the 870μm emission in the 8μm clumps as well as diffuse emission around them. From the LABOCA map, we can estimate the expected flux in the rectangular field. This leads to a desired mosaic sensitivity of 0.09mJy/beam. According to the ALMA OT, this requires 1.88min on source per pointing, so a total 12m array time (including the overlap of the mosaic fields) of 1.23h.
IR and submm maps of the galaxy indicate that we should expect contiguous features between the various clumps in the field, so we fix the largest angular structure in source to the typical separation between clumps, 11”. As this is larger than the maximum recoverable scale, structures larger than this will be recovered using the Atacama Compact Array. This adds a total ACA time of 2.47 hours.
The total time needed to reach our science goal is 3.70h.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Probing the dust emission and submm excess in Band 7 in NGC 1512
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to map the dust continuum emission and the CO(3-2) line emission with ALMA in Band 7 for an extranuclear region of NGC1512. We aim to characterise the location of the submm emission that appears in excess compared to Herschel predictions by comparing it with other tracers of the interstellar medium. A 2" resolution will allow us to spatially relate the regions where the cold dust dominates with the PAH carriers or with the molecular gas reservoirs at the same resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to observe the dust continuum and the CO(3-2) line at 345 GHz in band 7 in NGC1512. We choose an angular resolution of 2” in order to match the resolution of the Spitzer/8μm maps (1.9” resolution). This will allow to spatially compare the distribution of the cold dust distribution with respect to the PAH carriers as well as the molecular gas reservoirs.
For the correlator setup, we select the single continuum spectral type, with dual polarisation and 4 spectral windows. The setups for band 7 will also allow us to obtain a CO(3-2) line measurement at the same angular resolution. This will be the first observation of molecular gas in this object. We choose a sky frequency of 343.7 GHz to include the CO(3-2) line in Baseband-2. We choose a bandwidth of 2000 MHz (large velocity range for continuum measurements), with an element resolution of 31.250 MHz, resulting in a velocity resolution of 27.9 km/s.
We are requesting an extranuclear mosaic of 33” by 32”, with an position angle of 148 ̊. This mosaic will require 11 pointings (using the default Nyquist sampling) of the 12m array. The sensitivity required is estimated in order to allow the detection of the 870μm emission in the 8μm clumps as well as diffuse emission around them. From the LABOCA map, we can estimate the expected flux in the rectangular field. This leads to a desired mosaic sensitivity of 0.07mJy/beam. According to the ALMA OT, this requires 3.21min on source per pointing, so a total 12m array time (including the overlap of the mosaic fields) of 1.35h.
IR and submm maps of the galaxy indicate that we should expect contiguous features between the various clumps in the field, so we fix the largest angular structure in source to the typical separation between clumps, 11”. As this is larger than the maximum recoverable scale, structures larger than this will be recovered using the Atacama Compact Array. This adds a total ACA time of 2.70 hours.
The total time needed to reach our science goal is 4.05h.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Probing the dust emission and submm excess in Band 7 in NGC337
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose to map the dust continuum emission and the CO(3-2) line emission with ALMA in Band 7 for an extranuclear region of NGC337. We aim to characterise the location of the submm emission that appears in excess compared to Herschel predictions by comparing it with other tracers of the interstellar medium. A 2" resolution will allow us to spatially relate the regions where the cold dust dominates with the PAH carriers or with the molecular gas reservoirs mapped at the same resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to observe the dust continuum and the CO(3-2) line at 345 GHz in band 7 in NGC337. We choose an angular resolution of 2” in order to match the resolution of the Spitzer/8μm maps (1.9” resolution). This will allow to spatially compare the distribution of the cold dust distribution with respect to the PAH carriers as well as the molecular gas reservoirs.
For the correlator setup, we select the single continuum spectral type, with dual polarisation and 4 spectral windows. The setups for band 7 will also allow us to obtain a CO(3-2) line measurement at the same angular resolution. We choose a sky frequency of 342.5 GHz to include the CO(3-2) line in Baseband-2. We choose a bandwidth of 2000 MHz (large velocity range for continuum measurements), with an element resolution of 31.250 MHz, resulting in a velocity resolution of 27.9 km/s.
We are requesting an extranuclear mosaic of 27” by 24”, with an position angle of 150 ̊. This mosaic will require 14 pointings (using the default Nyquist sampling) of the 12m array. The sensitivity required is estimated in order to allow the detection of the 870μm emission in the 8μm clumps as well as diffuse emission around them. From the LABOCA map, we can estimate the expected flux in the rectangular field. This leads to a desired mosaic sensitivity of 0.08mJy/beam. According to the ALMA OT, this requires 2.36min on source per pointing, so a total 12m array time (including the overlap of the mosaic fields) of 1.25h.
IR and submm maps of the galaxy indicate that we should expect contiguous features between the various clumps in the field, so we fix the largest angular structure in source to the typical separation between clumps, 11”. As this is larger than the maximum recoverable scale, structures larger than this will be recovered using the Atacama Compact Array. This adds a total ACA time of 2.51 hours.
The total time needed to reach our science goal is 3.76h.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map both the dust continuum and the CO(3-2) line emission with ALMA Band 7 in extranuclear regions of 3 nearby spirals. A 2" resolution will allow us to study the spatial distribution of the submm emission with respect to PAHs or molecular gas reservoirs mapped with ALMA at the same resolution (for the first time for 2 of the 3 galaxies). These comparisons will enable us to study the dust formation mechanisms in disks, in particular the PAH formation, and to resolve the dust continuum emission to probe the sites where the submm excess detected in our three objects could be produced.
